Engineering the morphology of the support is effective in tuning the redox properties of active metals for efficient catalytic methane combustion via tailoring the metal-support interaction. Herein, uniform Ir nanoparticles supported on anatase TiO2 with different morphologies predominantly exposing {100}, {101}, and {001} planes were synthesized and tested for methane combustion. The CH4 catalytic activity shows a remarkable TiO2-facet-dependent effect and follows the order of Ir/TiO2-{100} > Ir/TiO2-{101} » Ir/TiO2-{001}. Detailed characterizations and DFT calculations reveal that compared with Ir-TiO2-{101} and Ir-TiO2-{001} interfaces, the superior Ir-TiO2-{100} interface facilitates the generation of electron-rich Ir species through more profound charge transfer from TiO2-{100} to Ir atoms. The electron-rich Ir structure, featuring abundant defect oxygen vacancies, significantly enhances the redox properties of active Ir species and reduces the activation energy for breaking the initial C-H bond in CH4, resulting in the superior catalytic activity for methane combustion. These findings deepen fundamental insights into the TiO2-facet-dependent reactivity of different Ir/TiO2 nanomaterials in methane oxidation and pave the way for designing efficient Ir-based methane oxidation catalysts. Graphical Abstract The electron-rich Ir structure, with abundant defect oxygen vacancies in Ir/TiO2-{100} catalysts, greatly enhances the redox properties of active Ir species and reduces C-H bond dissociation in CH4, resulting in the superior catalytic activity for methane combustion. Keywords Ir/TiO2 TiO2-facet-dependent Methane combustion Oxygen vacancies Metal-support interaction 1 Introduction Methane is increasingly recognized as a clean energy source, widely utilized in thermal power generation, household heating, gas turbines, and various industrial applications. However, it is also a potent greenhouse gas, possessing a global warming potential 34 times greater than that of CO2 over a century [ 1–3 ]. The high structural symmetry of methane, coupled with its strong C-H bond energy (439 kJ/mol), presents significant challenges for activation under mild conditions [ 4–6 ]. Traditional flame combustion of methane typically requires temperatures exceeding 1400 °C, resulting in the emission of harmful byproducts such as NO x and CO, etc. [ 7 ]. By comparison, the catalytic combustion of methane has emerged as a vital approach for clean energy utilization and emissions control. Recently, supported Ir-based catalysts have received increasing attention as promising candidates for methane oxidation, particularly those supported on TiO2, due to their remarkable ability to activate methane at low temperatures [ 8–11 ]. For example, Duan et al. [ 12 ] discovered that IrPt0.5/TiO2 nanomaterials display superior catalytic property and excellent sulfur resistance in methane combustion because Pt modified electron-rich Ir structures facilitate O2 activation while inhibiting sulfur dioxide adsorption. Rui et al. [ 13 ] synthesized Ir/TiO2 catalysts featuring well-dispersed IrO x /Ir active sites via strong metal support interaction (SMSI), which offered excellent low-temperature activity (T 99 = 320 °C) and stability in CH4 combustion. It is recognized that the crystal facet of the metal oxide significantly influences the surface chemistry properties, such as reducibility and acidity, of oxide-supported catalysts through metal-support interaction (MSI) [ 14–17 ]. Notably, the exposed facets are closely related to the morphology of the nanoparticles. Wang et al. [ 16 ] discovered CeO2-morphology-dependent catalytic property of Pd/CeO2 samples in total oxidation of CH4, which was closely related to the chemical states of Pd tuned via the interactions between Pd and the exposed CeO2 faces. Using in situ ambient pressure transmission electron microscopy (TEM), Wang et al. [ 17 ] discovered an oxidative facet-sensitive SMSI of Pd/TiO2. The obvious TiO x cover layers were formed on Pd/TiO2{101} and Pd/TiO2{100} at 550 °C in oxygen, whereas no TiO x layer appears on Pd/TiO2{001} catalyst. Hence, the methane oxidation activity of Pd/TiO2{101} and Pd/TiO2{100} samples significantly diminished owing to the oxidative SMSI under high temperature (550 °C). Efstathiou et al. [ 18 ], using transient and isotopic techniques, reported the CeO2-facet-dependent effect on the dry reforming of methane (DRM) over Ni/CeO2 and quantitatively addressed the influence of various nano-CeO2 morphologies on the gasification of deposited carbon during DRM via the surface and subsurface lattice oxygen of the ceria support. They discovered that compared to CeO2-NP, CeO2-NR exhibited lower activation energies for surface oxygen reduction, bulk oxygen diffusion, and carbon oxidation to CO(g) by the participation of the lattice oxygen of ceria support. The enhanced carbon gasification rates over Ni/CeO2-NR catalyst favored CO production and a concomitant reduction in carbon accumulation (ca. by 30%), thereby contributing to higher kinetic rates during DRM. It can be seen that the reactivity of the lattice oxygen species is highly dependent on the crystal plane of ceria support. In general, the reactivity of gas-phase oxygen and lattice oxygen species is essential for catalytic methane combustion. Besides the adsorption and activation of gas-phase oxygen, the reactivity and mobility of lattice oxygen in metal oxide supports could also significantly enhance the catalytic performance for methane combustion via boosting the redox property of active components [ 19,20 ]. However, to date, the TiO2-facet effects on supported Ir/TiO2 catalysts for methane combustion have not been explored. It is of great interest to elucidate the structure-property relation between exposed facets of TiO2 and reactivity for methane combustion reaction. Herein, we synthesized supported Ir/TiO2 catalysts with variable TiO2 morphology predominantly exposing the {001}, {100}, and {101} facets and investigated the TiO2-facet effects on the catalytic activity for CH4 combustion. It is observed that TiO2 facet significantly influences the catalytic property, with Ir/TiO2-{100} samples exhibiting best catalytic property for CH4 oxidation. The remarkable TiO2-facet-dependent effects were associated with different electronic metal support interaction (EMSI) and surface oxygen vacancies. Compared to the interfaces between Ir and TiO2-{101} or TiO2-{001}, a more profound electron transfer from TiO2-{100} to Ir occurs at Ir-TiO2-{100} interface, resulting in Ir species being in a negatively charged state. The electron-rich Ir structure, featuring abundant oxygen vacancies, significantly enhances the redox properties of active Ir species, and reduces the activation energy for breaking the initial C–H bond in CH4, thereby greatly promoting the methane oxidation activity. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst synthesis 2.1.1 Synthesis of Ti(OH)4 precursors First, a certain amount of titanium tetrachloride solution (6.6 mL) was introduced drop-by-drop into 0.43 mol L–1 HCl solution (20 mL), while maintaining a temperature of 0 °C. The mixed solution was kept for 30 min under continuous stirring. Subsequently, the mixture was introduced drop-by-drop into NH3·H2O solution (5.5 wt%, 50 mL) at 25 °C. The pH was tuned to the range of 6–7 using a specific amount of NH3·H2O solution (4 wt%), and stirring continued for another 2 h. Then the sediments were separated and rinsed multiple times with ultrapure water until no remaining Cl– ions were observed. Finally, the obtained powder was subjected to drying 12 h under 70 °C to yield Ti(OH)4 precursors. 2.1.2 Synthesis of anatase TiO2-{100} and TiO2-{101} supports The preparation of the two TiO2 nanomaterials followed the procedures outlined by Liu et al. [ 21 ]. For anatase TiO2-{100}, a specific amount of (NH4)2SO4 (0.5 g) and Ti(OH)4 (2 g) was introduced into 30 ml mixed solution (iPrOH:H2O = 1:1) and agitated at 25 °C. Subsequently, the mixture solution was placed in a Teflon reaction vessel (50 mL) and maintained for 24 h under 180 °C. Finally, the sediment is filtered and rinsed using ultra-pure water several times. The TiO2-{100} nanocrystals were synthesized using a similar procedure, substituting the additives of NH4Cl (0.2 g) for the (NH4)2SO4 (0.5 g). 2.1.3 Synthesis of anatase TiO2-{001} supports The preparation of TiO2-{001} supports was performed following the methods described by Han et al. [ 22 ]. In general, a specific amount of HF solution (40 wt%, 3 mL) was transferred to tetrabutyl titanate (25 mL) and agitated at 25 °C. Subsequently, the mixed solution was placed in a Teflon reaction vessel (50 mL) and maintained for 24 h under 180 °C (Caution is advised when handling HF in Teflon!). The sediment was separated and rinsed multiple times with ethanol and H2O, and then transferred to an oven for drying under 70 °C for 12 h. The obtained powders were placed in a specific amount of NaOH solution (0.1 mol L–1, 700 mL) under agitating for 24 h at room temperature, and then rinsed multiple times with ultrapure H2O until the pH achieved between 7 and 8. 2.1.4 Preparation of Ir/TiO2 samples All Ir/TiO2 samples with three different morphologies were prepared using an ultrasonic-assisted wet impregnation method, utilizing H2IrCl6 as the Ir source. Typically, a specific amount of H2IrCl6 solution was introduced dropwise into 0.4 g of TiO2 powders under ultrasonic treatment at 25 °C for 30 min. Subsequently, the mixed substances were placed in an oven to dry overnight under 110 °C. The obtained powders were calcined in box furnace for 2 h under 500 °C and subsequently pretreated under 400 °C in the flow of 5% H2/Ar mixture for 1 h, ultimately designated as Ir/TiO2-{100}, Ir/TiO2-{101}, and Ir/TiO2-{001}, respectively. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometer (ICP-AES, Aglient 7700s) was applied to measure the Ir loadings of all catalysts. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) was performed on a DX2700 diffraction apparatus employing Cu Kα (wavelength: 1.54056 Å, 40 kV, 40 mA). Raman spectroscopy was performed on a Thermo Scientific DXR2 Microscopic Confocal Raman Spectrometer (532 nm). TEM and high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) images were acquired on a JEM-ARM200F microscope operating at 200 kV. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted on the Thermo Scientific K-Alpha apparatus equipped with monochromatic Al Kα radiation (1486.6 eV), calibrated against the C 1s position at 284.8 eV. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectroscopy of all samples was collected at 140 K using a Bruker A300 EMX-plus EPR spectrometer (9.087 GHz). Hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) spectra were acquired using a Micromeritics ChemiSorb 2920 instrument, in which 50 mg sample was put into a quartz tube and pre-treated at 300 °C for 1 h under 5% O2/Ar flow at 30 mL min–1, followed by cooling to ambient temperature. High-purity Ar gas (99.999%) was then introduced and maintained for 30 minutes at 30 mL min–1 to eliminate gaseous or weakly adsorbed O2. Subsequently, the catalysts were raised to 500 °C with a ramp of 5 °C min–1 under a 5% H2/Ar flow at 30 mL min–1. The obtained H2-TPR spectra were plotted using the same Y-scale units, and the H2 consumption was quantified by the reduction of CuO powder with a known amount. Temperature programmed desorption of NH3 (NH3-TPD) was conducted using the same apparatus, in which 200 mg of samples were pre-reduced in 5% H2/Ar mixture (18 mL min–1) for 1 h under 300 °C. After that, the system was cooled down to ambient temperature under N2 flow (30 mL min–1, 99.999%) and exposed to NH3 for 30 min at 30 mL min–1. Following this, high-purity N2 was injected and maintained for 30 min to eliminate any gaseous or weakly adsorbed NH3. Finally, the samples were raised to 700 °C with a ramp of 10 °C min–1 in N2 flow. In situ diffuse reflectance infrared spectroscopy (in-situ DRIFTS) measurements were performed using a Fourier Transform Infrared Spectrometer armed with an MCT detector (Thermo Fisher Scientific Nicolet iS50R, USA). The reaction cell was designed with an additional quartz pane to enhance signal gathering during irradiation. Prior to the experiment, the samples were pre-heated under argon flow at 30 mL min–1 under 300 °C for 1 h to remove the surface impurities, followed by ramping to 350 °C to collect background spectra. Sequentially, a flow of 0.2% CH4/Ar (25 mL min–1) was switched into the reaction cell under 350 °C for 30 min, with spectra obtained every ten minutes (0, 10, 20, 30 min). After this, Ar gas was flowed through the reaction cell for 10 min. Following this, 2% O2/Ar was switched onto the samples at 25 mL min–1, and the patterns were acquired at interval of 0, 10, 20, 30 min. 2.3 CH4 combustion test The catalytic performance for methane oxidation was assessed using a custom-built fixed-bed reactor, in which 100 mg samples, mixed with a specific amount of quartz sand (900 mg), were loaded in a quartz tube with an inner diameter of 8 mm. The methane oxidation test was conducted with a gas mixture consisting of 0.2% CH4/2% O2/Ar at 50 mL min–1, equivalent to gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 30000 mL h–1 g–1. Before the reaction, each sample underwent a pretreatment in the reaction gas under 350 °C for 1 h. Subsequently, the sample was raised to the target operating temperatures (5 °C min–1). In addition, a Koros-Nowak test [ 23,24 ] was carried out to check the heat and mass transport limitations on Ir/TiO2-{100} catalysts with different Ir loadings under same reaction conditions as the representative. The conversion of methane was maintained under 15% during the Koros-Nowak test. Typically, 50 mg of Ir/TiO2-{100} catalysts with different Ir loadings were diluted with 450 mg of SiC (1:9). Data on the conversion of CH4 were monitored when the reaction attained a steady condition, with CO2 being the only detected reaction product. An online gas chromatograph (SHIMADZU GC-2014) was employed to monitor the product components. The CH4 conversion (X CH4) was measured by employing the following formula: X CH4 = ([C CH4]in – [C CH4]out)/[C CH4]in × 100% in which [C CH4]in and [C CH4]out mean the concentrations of CH4 in the inlet and outlet gas, respectively. 2.4 Density functional theory (DFT) calculations DFT calculations were carried out using the Vienna ab-initio simulation package (VASP) code [ 25,26 ]. The generalized gradient approximation of Perdew Burke-Ernzerhof (GGA-PBE) was employed to determine the exchange-correlation energy [ 27 ]. The plane wave pseudopotential (PAW) technique was utilized to describe the interaction between the nucleus and electrons [ 28 ]. A plane-wave cutoff energy was set to 400 eV, and configuration models were optimized until the forces reached a convergence of 0.02 eV Å–1, with a self-consistent calculation threshold set to less than than 10–5 eV. During optimization, a Brillouin space with a 2×2×1 k-point mesh was employed, which was later increased to 4×4×2 k-point grid for electronic structure calculation. To prevent potential periodic interactions, adjacent slabs were separated by a vacuum region in 20 Å along the z-direction. The cracking of the initial C–H bond in CH4 was investigated employing the nudged elastic band (NEB) technique [ 29 ], with results further analyzed using the dimer method [ 30 ]. To accurately describe the surface adsorption of molecules, Van der Waals correction was implemented through the DFT-D3 method [ 31 ] in this study. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterizations The microstructures of three different TiO2 nanocrystals were identified using the TEM and HRTEM as the representative (Fig. 1 ). The three TiO2 nanocrystals displayed quite uniform morphologies with predominantly exposed {100}, {101}, and {001} facets, respectively. Based on Wulff’s rules, the percentages of {100}, {101}, and {001} facets on TiO2-{100}, TiO2-{101}, and TiO2-{001} nanocrystals were calculated to be around 80%, consistent well with previous reports [ 14,32,33 ]. For TiO2-{100} nanomaterials, the length is around 20-50 nm, and the width is between 10 and 20 nm. The dimension of TiO2-{101} nanomaterials is about 15–30 nm, and the size of TiO2-{001} nanocrystals is around 40–60 nm. In HRTEM images, the interplanar distance of 1.90, 3.52, and 2.38 Å correspond to {200}, {101}, and {004} facets, respectively [ 34 ]. As depicted in Fig. 2(A) , the pure TiO2-{100}, TiO2-{001}, and TiO2-{101} samples predominantly exhibit the characteristic peaks of anatase TiO2 (JCPDS No. 21-1272). The Raman spectra of three TiO2 supports exhibit three major characteristic peaks at ~398, ~515, and 636 cm–1, corresponding to vibrational characteristics of anatase TiO2 with B1g, A1g, and Eg, respectively [ 32,35 ]. Obviously, the intensity of Eg feature peaks is greater than that of A1g and B1g for TiO2-{100} and TiO2-{101}. Whereas the Eg vibration modes are much less intense than the A1g and B1g feature peaks for TiO2-{001} nanocrystals. This because the exposed {001} facets with unsaturated 5c-Ti and 2c-O on TiO2 decrease the intensity of the Eg symmetric O-Ti-O stretching vibration characteristics in the Raman spectrum, agreeing well with previous reports [ 36–38 ]. A sequence of supported Ir/TiO2 samples were then synthesized using ultrasonic-assisted impregnation method. The actual Ir contents (wt%) were measured to 0.43%, 0.41%, and 0.45% in Ir/TiO2-{001}, Ir/TiO2-{101}, and Ir/TiO2-{100} samples, respectively. In corresponding XRD and Raman spectra (Figs. 2(C) and (D)), the signals of three supported Ir/TiO2 catalysts are associated with pure TiO2 supports. No signal peaks of Ir or IrO x related species are detected, meaning that the Ir nanoparticles with low loadings are well-dispersed on various TiO2 supports, which aligns with the following TEM results. For Ir/TiO2-{100} and Ir/TiO2-{001} samples, a significant decrease in Raman band intensity was observed upon Ir loading. By contrast, the Raman band intensity of Ir/TiO2-{101} exhibits slightly changes owing to the weaker electronic interaction between Ir and TiO2-{101} carriers, which was further confirmed by the following calculations of charge density difference. The similar phenomena have been observed in previous reports where the stronger electronic interaction between Pt and TiO2, the weaker intensity of the Raman peaks [ 39 ]. The microstructures of the three supported Ir/TiO2 samples were characterized by the TEM images. As shown in Fig. 3 , the ultrafine Ir nanoparticles are uniformly dispersed on various TiO2 supports. In HRTEM images, the lattice spacing of 2.22 Å in various Ir/TiO2 catalysts can be indexed to Ir (111) facets [ 12 ]. As observed, the original morphology of TiO2 nanocrystals is well preserved after Ir loading, and the supported Ir nanoparticles exhibit similar size distributions of approximately 1.0–1.3 nm. The EDS-mapping of Ir/TiO2-{100} catalysts further confirmed the presence of well-dispersed Ir nanoparticles supported on TiO2 as the representative (Fig. S1). When the Ir loadings increased to 1.25 wt%, the ultrafine Ir nanoparticles with similar sizes (~1.4 nm) still well dispersed on TiO2-{100} supports due to the SMSI assisted redispersion [ 13 ], as shown in Fig. S2. 3.2 Catalytic activity for CH4 total oxidation The methane catalytic activity of different Ir/TiO2 samples was assessed under lean conditions. As depicted in Fig. 4 , Ir/TiO2-{100} samples exhibited significantly superior performance compared to Ir/TiO2-{101} and Ir/TiO2-{001} samples. Specifically, the temperatures at which 50% (T 50) and 90% (T 90) conversion occurred for the Ir/TiO2-{100} samples were 337 and 380 °C, respectively. In contrast, the Ir/TiO2-{101} catalysts displayed higher T 50 and T 90 values at 382 and 435 °C, respectively. What’s more, the Ir/TiO2-{001} catalysts showed almost no catalytic activity across the entire temperature range. Similarly, three TiO2 supports offered no catalytic activity throughout the testing temperature range (Fig. S3). These results suggested that the Ir species serve as the intrinsic active centers, and the facet of TiO2 support significantly influences the reactivity of active Ir sites during methane combustion. In addition, a Koros-Nowak test was conducted on Ir/TiO2-{100} catalysts with different Ir loadings. Compared to Ir/TiO2-{100} catalysts with 0.45 wt% Ir loadings, when the Ir loadings increased to 1.25 wt%, the turnover frequency (TOF) at 300 °C remained almost unchanged under the same reaction conditions, as illustrated in Table S1. This suggested that the heat and mass transport effects are negligible, i. e., the reaction rate is not limited by mass or heat transport, but rather is kinetically controlled. However, a further increase in temperature may shift the reaction beyond kinetic control. This phenomenon has been observed previously, i.e., oxidation reaction is initiated at a temperature that depends on the hydrocarbon and the catalyst. A further increase in temperature leads to an exponential increase in the rate, where mass and heat transfer effects may be involved at higher temperatures [ 40 ]. As expected, CO2 selectivity was 100% because CO2 is the only detected products in the whole reaction. The space-time-yield (STY) of CO2 was also calculated, as shown in Fig. S4. The STY of CO2 over Ir/TiO2-{100} and Ir/TiO2-{101} samples continuously increases as the temperature increases, reaching its maximum value at 400 °C (23.1 gCO2 kgcat h–1) and 450 °C (21.1 gCO2 kgcat h–1), respectively. Beyond these temperatures, the space-time yield of CO2 gradually decreases. This, in turn, reflects that the methane reaction rate reaches its peak at 400 and 450 °C across the entire temperature range (200–500 °C). And the specific catalytic activity data are illustrated in Table S2. 3.3 Understand the facet-dependent effect on catalytic activity over Ir/TiO2 catalysts The surface electronic structures of three Ir/TiO2 catalysts with various morphologies were analyzed using XPS technology. As illustrated in Fig. 5 , Ir/TiO2-{100} samples displayed Ir 4f 7/2 features with the binding energies located at 60.5 and 61.6 eV, corresponding to Ir0 and Ir δ+ species [ 41–44 ], respectively, although the Ti 3s and Ir 4f peaks overlapped. Compared with Ir/TiO2-{100} samples, Ir 4f 7/2 features of Ir/TiO2-{101} and Ir/TiO2-{001} slightly shift to positive binding energy at around 60.7/61.8 and 60.8/62.0 eV, respectively. Meanwhile, the surface proportion of Ir0/(Ir δ++Ir0) in Ir/TiO2-{100} (0.60) catalysts is higher compared to that in Ir/TiO2-{101} (0.50) and Ir/TiO2-{001} (0.45). This suggests that the superior interface interaction between Ir and TiO2-{100} facilitates the reduction of Ir species. Analysis of the Ti 2p (Fig. 5(C)) indicates that the binding energy of Ti 2p 3/2 of Ir/TiO2-{100} is slightly positive compared to that of Ir/TiO2-{101} and Ir/TiO2-{001}, further supporting the generation of electron-rich Ir species through the profound charge transfer of TiO2 → Ir on Ir/TiO2-{100} samples. The O 1s XPS spectrum of all samples (Fig. 5(B)) can be resolved into two components at 530.0 and 531.5 eV, referring to lattice oxygen (Olatt) and surface-bound oxygen (Oads) species, respectively. And the Oads ratios of Ir/TiO2-{100} (0.21) are much greater than those of Ir/TiO2-{101} (0.16) and Ir/TiO2-{001} (0.13), which are closely related to an increased number of oxygen vacancy defects on the Ir/TiO2-{100} surface. After pre-treatment under the reaction gas, a portion of metallic Ir0 in Ir/TiO2-{100} and Ir/TiO2-{101} samples was further oxidized to Ir δ+ species as shown in Fig. S5. Additionally, the Oads ratios of Ir/TiO2-{100} (0.21 → 0.26) and Ir/TiO2-{101} samples (0.16 → 0.21) both increased after activation by the reaction gas. In contrast, for Ir/TiO2-{001} samples, the surface proportion of Ir0/(Ir δ++Ir0) (0.45) and Oads ratio (0.13) remained almost unchanged. Ti 2p XPS spectra also showed negligible changes before and after pre-treatment. These results suggested that metallic Ir0 was readily oxidized to Ir δ+ species in Ir/TiO2-{100} and Ir/TiO2-{101} catalysts, whereas Ir/TiO2-{001} was inactive for methane oxidation. Furthermore, the Oads ratios of Ir/TiO2-{100} were higher than those of Ir/TiO2-{101} and Ir/TiO2-{001} catalysts, both before and after pre-treatment, indicating that Ir/TiO2-{100} catalysts possess superior redox property, which enhanced methane oxidation activity. Table S3 illustrates the detail ratio data. The reducibility performance of all Ir/TiO2 samples was assessed using the H2-TPR experiments. As shown in Fig. 6(A) , all curves exhibited three signal peaks in the temperature zone between 50–500 °C, corresponding to the reduction of different Ir δ+ species [ 41,44 ]. Wherein, the α (98–131 °C) signal is ascribed to the reduction of surface Ir δ+ that is not attached to the supports. The β (215–235 °C) and γ (402–413 °C) signals are linked to the reduction of Ir δ+ attaching with various interaction force with TiO2 supports, as well as partially TiO2 adjacent to iridium metals due to the spillover effect. In contrast, Ir/TiO2-{100} catalysts exhibited relatively lower H2 reduction temperature (~98, 215, and 402 °C, respectively) compared to Ir/TiO2-{101} (~122, 235, and 413 °C, respectively) and Ir/TiO2-{001} (~131, 235, and 413 °C, respectively). Furthermore, the H2 consumption of Ir/TiO2-{100} (0.37 mmol g–1) catalysts is higher than that of Ir/TiO2-{101} (0.28 mmol g–1) and Ir/TiO2-{001} (0.11 mmol g–1) catalysts (Table S3). These suggest that the superior interface interaction between Ir and TiO2-{100} promotes the reduction of Ir δ+ species, which is associated with the enhanced redox properties of Ir/TiO2-{100} samples. The enhanced reducibility was further corroborated by the following EPR results. The EPR technique was performed to investigate the defect textures of all Ir/TiO2 catalysts. Ir/TiO2-{100} and Ir/TiO2-{101} exhibits a feature at 2.018 stemming from the O2 - species, and another distinct signal at 2.002 coming from the single-electron oxygen defect (Fl+ color center) [ 32 ]. Additionally, a small feature peak at g = 1.982 associated with the subsurface/bulk Ti3+ bulk defects appears in all Ir/TiO2 catalysts. Generally, the O2 – substances are derived from the uptake of O2 on the surface F1+ sites of TiO2 in the ambient atmosphere. Obviously, the concentration of F1+ signals in the Ir/TiO2-{100} samples is significantly higher compared to the Ir/TiO2-{101} catalysts. For Ir/TiO2-{001} samples, the characteristic peaks of O2 – and Fl+ color center were almost no visible. The intensity order of F1+ color centers in different Ir/TiO2 samples is well parallel to their catalytic activities. It can be inferred that the more defective oxygen vacancies there are, the better the redox properties of Ir/TiO2 samples, which aligns with the above H2-TPR results. As shown in NH3-TPD spectra, the Ir/TiO2-{101} and Ir/TiO2-{100} samples exhibit significantly stronger surface acidity than the Ir/TiO2-{001} catalysts with only a few weak acid sites (α, 100-200 °C). Additionally, Ir/TiO2-{100} samples provided a greater quantity of moderate (β, 200–350 °C) and strong acid sites (γ, 350–500 °C) compared to Ir/TiO2-{101} samples. The stronger surface acidity of Ir/TiO2-{100} samples could promote CH4 molecule adsorption/activation on the surface of catalysts, which was further confirmed by the following DFT results, thereby enhancing methane oxidation activity. This phenomenon has also been previously observed by Duan et al. [ 45 ], who reported that the acid-etched La0.8Sr0.2MnO3 catalysts with stronger surface acidity promote CH4 molecule adsorption/activation and the desorption of catalytic reaction products, ultimately leading to improved catalytic activity for methane oxidation. The in situ DRIFTS spectra were performed to monitor 0.2% CH4 and 2% O2 adsorption over various Ir/TiO2 catalysts at 350 °C. As shown in Fig. 7 , when 0.2% CH4/Ar was introduced into the reaction cell, gaseous CH4 signals (δ C–H: 1301 cm–1 and ν C–H: 3012 cm–1) were identified over the three different Ir/TiO2 samples. In addition, another weak signal around 1340 cm–1 is assigned to the asymmetric vibration of CH x species [ 46,47 ], indicating that the CH4 can be activated to CH x on the surface of samples. From the time-resolved DRIFTS spectra (Figs. S6–S8), we can see that the intensity of CH4 and CH x peaks increased with increasing the time in Ir/TiO2-{100} and Ir/TiO2-{101} samples, whereas the intensity of CH4 and CH x species on Ir/TiO2-{001} samples remained nearly unchanged as time increased. This indicated that Ir/TiO2-{100} and Ir/TiO2-{101} samples possess better methane adsorption and activation performances than Ir/TiO2-{001} catalysts. After O2 was switched into the cell, there were almost no peaks associated with CH x and other intermediates except the weak CH4 vibrations at 3012 cm–1, suggesting that the small amount of CH x species derived from CH4 activation are easily desorbed and no further reaction takes place on the surface of Ir/TiO2-{001} samples. For Ir/TiO2-{101} catalysts, the characteristic bands of carbonate-type species (1358, 1401, 1434, 1538 cm–1) were observed after O2 was introduced into the reaction cell [ 3,48,49 ], indicating that CH4 and CH x species undergo further activation and reaction with gas O2 on the catalyst surface. Simultaneously, chemisorbed H2O emerged at 3673 cm–1 due to the methane oxidation reaction. Interestingly, as for Ir/TiO2-{100} catalysts upon introducing the O2, the formate intermediates (1574, 1613 cm–1) [ 47,50–52 ] formed at the expense of carbonate-type species (1350–1540 cm–1). Meanwhile, the band of CH4 completely disappeared and CH3O species (2964 cm–1) appeared on the surface. The CH3O species can be derived from the subsequent reaction between the CH x and surface –OH species on the Ir/TiO2-{100} catalysts [ 53,54 ]. Greater methane consumption on Ir/TiO2-{100} catalysts suggested that Ir/TiO2-{100} catalysts possess better catalytic activity for methane oxidation than Ir/TiO2-{101} catalysts. It should be noted that DRIFTS alone cannot completely rule out the formation of carbonates, which could arise from the readsorption of CO2 product during methane oxidation. Combining DRIFTS with the SSITKA technique could provide a more compelling approach for understanding the nature of surface-adsorbed species–both active and inactive–as well as the mechanistic insights during methane combustion reactions. Efstathiou et al. [ 55 ] and Dujardin et al. [ 56 ] have successfully utilized the SSITKA-DRIFTS technique to identify both active and inactive intermediate species during the water-gas shift and CO oxidation reactions, respectively. To accurately identify in situ reaction intermediates (both active and inactive species) and gain a better mechanistic understanding of methane combustion over Ir/TiO2 catalysts, we may need to conduct SSITKA-DRIFTS experiments to identify the active reaction intermediates, along with first-principles kinetic simulations to model the experimental kinetics, however, which are beyond the scope of the present paper. In our future work, considerable efforts will be dedicated to completing this study. 3.4 DFT calculations The charge density difference was first calculated to understand the interfacial electronic metal-support interaction between Ir and TiO2 carrier (Figs. 8(A)–(C) ). For Ir/TiO2-{100} samples, an obvious electron accumulation with 0.29 e was found at Ir sites via the profound charge transfer of TiO2-{100}→Ir atoms. By contrast, less electron transfer was identified for Ir/TiO2-{101} and Ir/TiO2-{001} model, i.e. about 0.12 e and 0.18 e, respectively. The profound charge transfer from TiO2-{100} to Ir further confirmed the formation of electron rich Ir species, which aligns with the above XPS results. As depicted in Fig. S9, the CH4 adsorption energies at the Ir sites of Ir/TiO2-{100} (–0.43 eV) was significantly enhanced compared to Ir/TiO2-{101} and Ir/TiO2-{001} samples (0.15 eV and 1.03 eV, respectively). We further calculated the density of states (DOS) for bare and CH4-adsorbed Ir/TiO2 catalysts (Figs. S10–S12). Compared to bare Ir/TiO2-{101} (–2.935 eV) and Ir/TiO2-{001} (–3.031 eV), the d-band center (E d) of Ir sites for bare Ir/TiO2-{100} (–2.898 eV) is situated closer to the Fermi level. More interestingly, upon CH4 adsorption, the E d of Ir for Ir/TiO2-{100} shows a slightly negative shift (–2.898 eV → –2.929 eV) than that for Ir/TiO2-{101} (–2.935 eV → –3.001 eV) and Ir/TiO2-{001} (–3.031 eV → –3.124 eV). The DOS calculations combined with in situ DRIFTS spectra suggested that Ir/TiO2-{001} samples are inactive for methane adsorption and activation, which is likely the primary reason for Ir/TiO2-{001} catalysts being nearly inactive for CH4 combustion, rather than coke formation poisoning the supported Ir particles despite the inherent inertness of TiO2-{001} in activating O2. In contrast, Ir/TiO2-{100} catalysts exhibit superior CH4 adsorption and activation ability, i.e., possess better redox capacity. These results highlight the important role of the oxidation state of active Ir species in determining CH4 adsorption and activation. Electron-rich Ir structures (i.e., Ir species being in a negatively charged state) induced by profound EMSI in Ir/TiO2-{100} catalysts are more favorable for activation of methane than stoichiometric IrO2 and metallic Ir0. This was consistent with previous reports [ 8,10 ] suggesting that partially reduced IrO2 exhibits better activity toward CH4 activation than both metallic Ir and stoichiometric IrO2. Meanwhile, Ir/TiO2-{100} has a stronger ability to absorb O2 (Fig. S13). Moreover, the activation energy barrier for the initial C-H bond cracking (1.40 eV) of CH4 on IrO2/TiO2-{100} catalysts was much lower than that on IrO2/TiO2-{101} (1.98 eV) and IrO2/TiO2-{001} (2.25 eV) catalysts (Figs. 8(D) and (E)). These results strongly prove that the superior Ir-TiO2-{100} interface significantly enhances the redox capacity of the catalysts and lowers the energy barrier for initial C–H bond cracking, leading to better catalytic activity for the total oxidation of methane. 4 Conclusions In summary, the Ir/TiO2-{100}, Ir/TiO2-{101}, and Ir/TiO2-{001} samples with uniform Ir particle size were successfully synthesized and tested for methane oxidation. It was observed that the facet of TiO2 has a significant impact on catalytic property, with Ir/TiO2-{100} exhibiting the best catalytic performance. The remarkable TiO2-facet-dependent effects were closely associated with different EMSI and surface oxygen vacancies. Compared with Ir/TiO2-{101} and Ir/TiO2-{001} samples, Ir/TiO2-{100} samples have a more profound electron transfer from TiO2-{100} to Ir, making Ir into the negatively charged state. The electron-rich Ir structure, featuring abundant oxygen vacancies, greatly promotes the redox properties of active Ir species and favors C–H bond dissociation in CH4, leading to superior catalytic activity for methane combustion. These findings significantly deepen essential insight of TiO2-facet-dependent reactivity of Ir/TiO2 nanomaterials in CH4 combustion and open a new avenue to designing efficient Ir-based methane oxidation catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Engineering the morphology of the support is effective in tuning the redox properties of active metals for efficient catalytic methane combustion via tailoring the metal-support interaction. Herein, uniform Ir nanoparticles supported on anatase TiO2 with different morphologies predominantly exposing {100}, {101}, and {001} planes were synthesized and tested for methane combustion. The CH4 catalytic activity shows a remarkable TiO2-facet-dependent effect and follows the order of Ir/TiO2-{100} > Ir/TiO2-{101} » Ir/TiO2-{001}. Detailed characterizations and DFT calculations reveal that compared with Ir-TiO2-{101} and Ir-TiO2-{001} interfaces, the superior Ir-TiO2-{100} interface facilitates the generation of electron-rich Ir species through more profound charge transfer from TiO2-{100} to Ir atoms. The electron-rich Ir structure, featuring abundant defect oxygen vacancies, significantly enhances the redox properties of active Ir species and reduces the activation energy for breaking the initial C-H bond in CH4, resulting in the superior catalytic activity for methane combustion. These findings deepen fundamental insights into the TiO2-facet-dependent reactivity of different Ir/TiO2 nanomaterials in methane oxidation and pave the way for designing efficient Ir-based methane oxidation catalysts.
